questions.text: Which of the nerves passes from the superior part of the superior orbital fissure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4th nerve The superior orbital fissure is divided into three parts by the annulus of Zinn . The superior part is crossed by Lacrimal N, Frontal N, Trochlear N, and the superior ophthalmic vein. The superior orbital fissure is divided into three parts by the annulus of Zinn . The superior part is crossed by Lacrimal N, Frontal N, Trochlear N, and the superior ophthalmic vein.

Highyeild:

The superior orbital fissure transmits the oculomotor nerve (superior and inferior divisions), abducens nerve, nasociliary nerve, lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve (all three are branches of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve), trochlear nerve, and also the superior ophthalmic vein and branch of the inferior ophthalmic vein.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Superior & inferior division of 3rd nerve Option: D. Nasociliary N Option: C. Abducents N pass through the middle part of the superior orbital fissure . The inferior ophthalmic vein crosses the inferior part.

Extraedge:

The orbit is divided into four self-contained spaces, namely (from outside to inside) the subperiosteal space, the peripheral orbital space, the central intraconal space, and the Tenon space. The greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone bound the superior orbital fissure . The optic foramen is situated between the lesser wing and the body of the sphenoid bone.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with bruises over his left eye after getting in a fight. On examination, the superior gaze was restricted. A fracture of the orbital floor is suspected. Which of the statements is false regarding the anatomy of orbit?

options.label: A
options.text: The orbit is divided into four self-contained spaces

options.label: B
options.text: The greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone bound the superior orbital fissure.

options.label: C
options.text: Ophthalmic artery passes through the superior orbital fissure

options.label: D
options.text: The optic foramen is situated between the lesser wing and body of the sphenoid bone.

questions.correct_answer: C. Ophthalmic artery passes through the superior orbital fissure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ophthalmic artery passes through the superior orbital fissure The ophthalmic artery passes through the optic foramen along with its sympathetic plexus, and optic nerve. The superior orbital fissure transmits the oculomotor nerve (superior and inferior divisions), abducens nerve, nasociliary nerve, lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve (all three are branches of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve), the trochlear nerve, and also the superior ophthalmic vein and branch of the inferior ophthalmic vein.

Highyeild:

The superior orbital fissure is bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . The orbit is divided into four self-contained spaces , namely (from outside to inside) the subperiosteal space, the peripheral orbital space, the central intraconal space, and the Tenon space. Option: B . The greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone bound the superior orbital fissure . Option: D. The optic foramen is situated between the lesser wing and body of the sphenoid bone.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of diplopia. On examination, there is ophthalmoplegia and ptosis but normal vision. A diagnosis of superior orbital fissure syndrome is made. Which of the following structures pass through the superior orbital fissure? Optic nerve Ophthalmic artery Oculomotor nerve Abducens nerve Nasociliary nerve Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

iii, iv, v The superior orbital fissure transmits the oculomotor nerve (superior and inferior divisions), abducens nerve, nasociliary nerve, lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve (all three are branches of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve) trochlear nerve and also the superior ophthalmic vein and branch of inferior ophthalmic vein.

Highyeild:

The superior orbital fissure is bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, D. The optic nerve, ophthalmic artery and sympathetic plexus of the artery passes through the optic foramen and not the superior orbital fissure.

Extraedge:

The orbit is divided into four self-contained spaces, namely (from outside to inside) the subperiosteal space, the peripheral orbital space, the central intraconal space and Tenon space. The superior orbital fissure is bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone. The optic foramen is situated between the lesser wing and the body of the sphenoid bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the anatomy of the orbit?

options.label: A
options.text: The optic foramen is bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone

options.label: B
options.text: The dural sheath of the optic nerve is adherent to the optic foramen

options.label: C
options.text: The recti muscles originate from the annulus of Zinn.

options.label: D
options.text: The orbit is divided into four self-contained spaces

questions.correct_answer: A. The optic foramen is bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The optic foramen is bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone The optic foramen is situated between the lesser wing and the body of the sphenoid bone. The orbit is divided into four self-contained spaces, namely (from outside to inside) the subperiosteal space, the peripheral orbital space, the central intraconal space, and the Tenon space.

Highyeild:

The superior orbital fissure is bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone. The optic foramen is situated between the lesser wing and the body of the sphenoid bone .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . The optic nerve passes through the optic foramen and its dural sheath is adherent to the walls of the optic foramen . Option: C . The recti muscles originate from the annulus of Zinn which is a common tendinous ring at the apex of the orbit. Option: D . The orbit is divided into four self-contained spaces , namely (from outside to inside) (i) The subperiosteal space between the orbital wall and the periorbital (ii) The peripheral orbital (extraconal) space between the periorbita and the extraocular muscles (iii) The central intraconal space, a cone-shaped area enclosed by the muscles and (iv) Tenon space around the globe.

Extraedge:

With unilateral third cranial nerve palsy (i.e., oculomotor nerve palsy) , the involved eye usually is deviated "down and out" (i.e., infraducted and abducted) , and there may be partial or complete ptosis. In addition, pupillary dilatation can cause anisocoria (greater in the light), symptomatic glare in bright light, and accommodation deficit that may cause blurred vision for near objects.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man complains of sudden onset pain and swelling of the lids. On examination, the lid is oedematous with raised temperature and tenderness. Visual acuity is normal. Which of the following is true about spaces around the orbit?

options.label: A
options.text: Peripheral orbital space is enclosed by extraocular muscles

options.label: B
options.text: The central space is present between the periorbita and extraocular muscles.

options.label: C
options.text: Tenon's space forms the central intraconal space.

options.label: D
options.text: Subperiosteal space is between the bones of the orbital wall and periorbital

questions.correct_answer: D. Subperiosteal space is between the bones of the orbital wall and periorbital
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subperiosteal space is between the bones of the orbital wall and periorbital The clinical picture represents a case of Preseptal cellulitis , a bacterial infection of the eyelid anterior to the orbital septum and is due to trauma or the spread of infection from surrounding structures. Patients complain of acute onset pain and swelling of the lids .

Highyeild:

Differential Diagnosis: Bacterial infection of the orbital contents (orbital cellulitis) presents with proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and ocular pain. Patients with orbital cellulitis typically have a fever, a source of infection (rhinosinusitis, dacryocystitis, acute otitis media), and pain in extraocular movements, which are absent in this patient.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The peripheral orbital or extraconal space is present between the periorbita and extraocular muscles Option: B. The central or intraconal space is a cone-shaped area enclosed by extraocular muscles. Option: C. Tenon capsule is the fascia which forms a socket in which the globe moves. Tenon space is formed around the globe.

Extraedge:

On examination, the lid is oedematous with raised temperature and tenderness. Visual acuity and ocular motility are normal, and no signs of proptosis.

questions.text: Which is the following is the incorrect pair in the image ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C = Oculomotor nerve The label C represents the trochlear nerve and not oculomotor nerve. The third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerves innervate the extraocular muscles that position the globes in the orbits. Extraocular muscle paralysis resulting from lesions in one or all of these cranial nerves results in the failure of one or both eyes to rotate in concert with the other eye. The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axes, and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved. With unilateral third cranial nerve palsy (i.e., oculomotor nerve palsy) , the involved eye usually is deviated "down and out" (i.e., infraducted and abducted) , and there may be partial or complete ptosis. In addition, pupillary dilatation can cause anisocoria (greater in the light), symptomatic glare in bright light, and accommodation deficit that may cause blurred vision for near objects.

Highyeild:

A painful pupil -involved oculomotor nerve palsy may result from a life-threatening intracranial aneurysm . Therefore, recognition of oculomotor nerve palsy is critical to ensure prompt and appropriate evaluation and treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Label A correctly represents the sixth cranial nerve, the abducens nerve. Option: B. Nasociliary nerve is labelled with B. It is the branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and enters orbit through superior orbital fissure Option: D. D represents the optic nerve that enters the orbit via the optic foramen along with the ophthalmic artery.

Extraedge:

3rd Nerve Palsy - The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axis , and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the third cranial nerve?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and C Both C and A represent the superior and inferior division of the oculomotor nerve, respectively . The third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerves innervate the extraocular muscles that position the globes in the orbits. Extraocular muscle paralysis resulting from lesions in one or all of these cranial nerves results in the failure of one or both eyes to rotate in concert with the other eye. The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axes, and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved. With unilateral third cranial nerve palsy (i.e., oculomotor nerve palsy) , the involved eye usually is deviated "down and out" (i.e., infraducted and abducted) , and there may be partial or complete ptosis. In addition, pupillary dilatation can cause anisocoria (greater in the light), symptomatic glare in bright light, and accommodation deficit that may cause blurred vision for near objects.

Highyeild:

A painful pupil -involved oculomotor nerve palsy may result from a life-threatening intracranial aneurysm . Therefore, recognition of oculomotor nerve palsy is critical to ensure prompt and appropriate evaluation and treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. The label B represents the Nasociliary nerve which is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

Extraedge:

3rd Nerve Palsy - The primary symptom is diplopia caused by misalignment of the visual axis , and the pattern of Image separation is the key to diagnosing which particular ocular motor cranial nerve (and extraocular muscle) is involved.
